awd_titl_txt: Inverse Problems for Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed work has four major goals.  (1) The first goal is to further advance the work concerning cloaking-by-mapping. Particular emphasis will be placed on the physical relevance of the proposed meta-materials (used for the cloak), and on the potential for improvement in the relative cloaking rates of the approximate schemes. In the context of physical relevance, the goal is to study meta- materials that satify the socalled Kramers-Kronig relations (which  naturally emerge from causality considerations).  Initially these studies will focus on materials, which are governed by the socalled Drude-Lorentz model. It is also planned to perform a careful study of the similarities between the technique of perfectly matched layers (PML) and cloaking-by-mapping. (2) The second goal is to better estimate the presence of inhomogeneities, in particular their volume fraction, from the response to multiple boundary loads. The aim is to extend earlier low volume fraction results, obtained for small number of boundary measurements (n measurements in n dimensions). (3) The third goal is to study the uniqueness and stability of an inverse problem, in which one seeks to identify a (nonlinear) current flux from a single (Neumann) boundary measurement. The associated boundary value problem is motivated by the equations of magnetohydrodynamic equilibria. (4) The fourth and final goal is to study static and dynamic problems associated with corrosion and oxidation modelling. These studies will range from the construction of explicit solutions, to the study of boundary blow-up, and criteria for finite time blow-up vs. existence for all time.


There are significant possibilities for broader impact.  In the area of "cloaking-by-mapping", the kind of results, one can expect to obtain, will be extremely useful in determining the degree of "near invisibility" that is in practice achievable, given (physically relevant) limitations on the meta-materials, used to construct the cloaks. One can well imagine an interplay between the type of results expected, and the actual physical construction of approximate invisibility cloaks. The work on the estimation/detection of small inhomogeneities has already led to the development of algorithms of use in flaw detection and medical imaging. The improved bounds, for volume fractions, will have similar potential applications. While the studies of the identifiability of the electric flux in the context of magnetohydrodynamics will be mostly theoretical, it is clear that the study of stability properties, and of the benefits of using additional line-integral measurements, could have very practical applications in terms of the control of plasmas in Tokamak devices.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Most of the results obtained under this award are related to the cloaking and/or detection of imbedded objects. The probing fields are of an electromagnetic nature.

When the measured data are the (far-field) scattered data we have obtained striking results that (modulo a mild non-degeneracy condition) assert that only for smooth scatterers can one (possibly) find a wave number at which there exists an incident wave that doesn't exhibit any scattering. For the same type of measured data and perfectly smooth scatterers we have also shown that the number of potential wave numbers with a non-scattering incident wave is highly dependent on geometry. If one restricts attention to incident waves that are so-called Herglotz waves (a superposition of plane waves with a given density) then for the disk there exist infinitely many densities for each of which the corresponding Herglotz wave is non-scattering at infinitely many wave numbers. However, if the disk is perturbed to a proper ellipse then the Herglotz wave associated with a fixed density can at most have finitely many wave numbers at which it is non-scattering.

Many of the passive cloaks, studied mathematically so far, have been based on "materials" whose electromagnetic properties are independent of wave number. This is not physically realistic, and so our recent results about (the construction) of approximate passive cloaks at a broad range of frequencies have dealt with models (such as the Drude-Lorentz model) that are more realistic. We have obtained results in the frequency domain, as well as in the time domain, relating material properties to the approximate cloaking effect. To obtain a high degree of invisibility one must use materials whose properties are highly anisotropic, as well as nearly singular. In this context, we have studied the use of novel transformations (in the so-called cloaking my mapping approach) to cut down on anisotropy.

The study of approximate (passive) cloaks is intimately connected with the study of small internal inhomogeneities and their effect on the  boundary values of the fields, uniformly with respect to the contents of the inhomogeneities. To potentially develop approximate, partial cloaks that are less anisotropic our recent results have focused on "thin" inhomogeneities (as opposed to diametrically small inhomogenities) and their boundary effects, uniformly with respect to their contents. Using similar techniques (in combination with integral formulations) we have also obtained very precise estimates of the field effects associated with a change in the type of boundary conditions on small subsets of the boundary -- these results are of importance in certain optimal design contexts (not related to cloaks).


Last Modified: 09/26/2021
Modified by: Michael S Vogelius
